critique: This executive order amends a previous order to assign the United States Information Agency (USIA) responsibilities related to emergency preparedness and foreign information activities during national emergencies. It focuses on ensuring the USIA can continue its operations, promote understanding of the US within the US, advise the Executive Branch on foreign opinion, maintain liaison with friendly nations' information agencies, participate in psychological aspects of defense, maintain US information service staffs abroad, and lend support in psychological warfare. The order itself doesn't directly reflect a strong ideological tilt, immigration stance, or economic regulation approach. However, it does expand executive power by assigning these responsibilities to the USIA during emergencies. It also leans towards prioritizing national security during emergencies. There is no direct impact on federalism or social inclusion.
